title: Curiosity & Exploration
description: Discover how you explore new interests and experiences together.

questions.text: When it comes to trying new things, I tend to...
choices: Jump in enthusiastically
Research and prepare first
Need encouragement to start
Prefer to watch others do it first

therapeutic.rationale: Approach to new experiences reflects openness and risk tolerance. Enthusiasts embrace novelty; researchers minimize uncertainty; encouragement-needers require support; observers learn vicariously. Understanding this helps couples navigate new experiences together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different approaches to novelty can be complementary. The enthusiast can inspire while the researcher ensures safety. Meet in the middle.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared approach to new things creates natural synchrony when exploring together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you approach trying new things? What helps you step outside your comfort zone?

choices: Learning about people and relationships
Understanding how things work
Exploring new places and cultures
Developing skills and abilities

therapeutic.rationale: Curiosity domains reveal what energizes us. People-curious types love connection; mechanism-curious types love understanding; exploration-curious types love novelty; skill-curious types love mastery. Sharing curiosity creates connection.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different curiosity domains can enrich each other. Your partner's interests can expand your world.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared curiosity domains create natural overlap in what you want to explore together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What are you most curious about in life? How might you share that curiosity with your partner?

questions.text: When you're excited about something new, I...
choices: Get excited too and want to explore it with you
Love hearing about it even if it's not my thing
Am happy to support your interest
Sometimes wish you'd include me more

therapeutic.rationale: How we respond to our partner's interests affects connection. Joining creates shared experience; appreciating creates acceptance; supporting creates space; wanting inclusion signals connection needs. All responses are valid.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses to partner interests work together. The supporter creates space while the joiner creates connection. Balance both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched responses to partner interests create aligned expectations about involvement in each other's explorations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond when your partner is excited about something new? Is that what they need?

questions.text: Something I'd love for us to explore together is...
choices: A new hobby or creative pursuit
Travel to somewhere we've never been
A deeper understanding of each other
A skill we could learn as a team

therapeutic.rationale: Shared exploration aspirations point to growth opportunities. Hobbies create shared identity; travel creates memories; deeper understanding creates intimacy; team skills create collaboration. Naming desires helps make them happen.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different exploration desires aren't mutually exclusive. You can pursue multiple types of shared experiences.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared exploration desires create clear direction for your next adventure together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would you love to explore together? What's stopping you from starting?

questions.text: Exploring new things together helps us...
choices: Keep our relationship fresh and exciting
Learn more about each other
Create memories we'll treasure
Grow closer through shared experiences

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about exploration's value shape how couples prioritize novelty. Freshness prevents stagnation; learning deepens knowledge; memories create history; closeness strengthens bonds. Research shows shared novel experiences boost relationship satisfaction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these benefits are real. Shared exploration provides multiple forms of relationship nourishment.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared understanding of exploration's value creates motivation to keep trying new things together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does exploring new things together benefit your relationship? When did you last do this?
